rules.title: California Alcohol Beverage Control Act
rules.shortDescription: All establishments engaged in the production, distribution, or retail of alcoholic beverages must secure a license from the California Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control. Licensees must display their license prominently
rules.fullText: California Alcohol Beverage Control Act (Cal. Code Regs Title 4 §1-100): All establishments engaged in the production, distribution, or retail of alcoholic beverages must secure a license from the California Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control. Licensees must display their license prominently

rules.title: Federal Alcohol Administration Act
rules.shortDescription: Winemakers must comply with the labeling requirements for wine, including alcohol content, bottler's information, and health warnings. Non-compliance may result in penalties or suspension of production rights
rules.fullText: Federal Alcohol Administration Act (27 U.S.C. §201 et seq.): Winemakers must comply with the labeling requirements for wine, including alcohol content, bottler's information, and health warnings. Non-compliance may result in penalties or suspension of production rights

rules.title: California Direct-to-Consumer Wine Shipping
rules.shortDescription: Winery with an active winegrower license may ship wine directly to California consumers, provided they also register with the recipient state's regulatory body if shipped outside of California
rules.fullText: California Direct-to-Consumer Wine Shipping (Bus. & Prof. Code §23661.2): Winery with an active winegrower license may ship wine directly to California consumers, provided they also register with the recipient state's regulatory body if shipped outside of California

rules.title: Sonoma County Viticultural Regulations
rules.shortDescription: Winemakers must adhere to specific land use and zoning regulations, including limits on pesticide use and adherence to sustainable farming practices. Annual inspections are conducted to ensure compliance
rules.fullText: Sonoma County Viticultural Regulations (Sonoma County Code §26-88-200): Winemakers must adhere to specific land use and zoning regulations, including limits on pesticide use and adherence to sustainable farming practices. Annual inspections are conducted to ensure compliance

rules.title: California Redemption Value (CRV) Program
rules.shortDescription: Beverage containers, including wine bottles, sold in California are subject to the state's CRV program, which incentivizes recycling through a deposit system
rules.fullText: California Redemption Value (CRV) Program (Cal. Pub. Res. Code §§14500-14599): Beverage containers, including wine bottles, sold in California are subject to the state's CRV program, which incentivizes recycling through a deposit system

rules.title: Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA)
rules.shortDescription: Winemaking facilities are required to implement food safety practices, including a hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls (HARPC). Facilities must register with the FDA for inspection
rules.fullText: Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) (21 U.S.C. §2201 et seq.): Winemaking facilities are required to implement food safety practices, including a hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls (HARPC). Facilities must register with the FDA for inspection

rules.title: Organic Certification
rules.shortDescription: Winemakers labeling their products as 'organic' must comply with USDA organic standards. Certification involves annual inspections and maintaining organic integrity throughout the production process
rules.fullText: Organic Certification (National Organic Program, 7 CFR Part 205): Winemakers labeling their products as 'organic' must comply with USDA organic standards. Certification involves annual inspections and maintaining organic integrity throughout the production process

rules.title: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance (CSWA) Certification
rules.shortDescription: Winemakers seeking CSWA certification must meet established criteria for sustainable practices in vineyard and winery operations, undergo self-assessments, and participate in educational workshops
rules.fullText: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance (CSWA) Certification: Winemakers seeking CSWA certification must meet established criteria for sustainable practices in vineyard and winery operations, undergo self-assessments, and participate in educational workshops

rules.title: Sonoma County Water Conservation Ordinance
rules.shortDescription: Agricultural operations, including wineries, must adhere to specific water conservation measures, particularly during drought periods. This includes implementing water-saving irrigation systems and reporting usage
rules.fullText: Sonoma County Water Conservation Ordinance (Sonoma County Code §26-64): Agricultural operations, including wineries, must adhere to specific water conservation measures, particularly during drought periods. This includes implementing water-saving irrigation systems and reporting usage

rules.title: Sonoma County Noise Ordinance
rules.shortDescription: Winery events and agritourism activities must comply with county noise regulations, restricting loud operations during night hours to minimize disturbance to surrounding communities
rules.fullText: Sonoma County Noise Ordinance (Sonoma County Code §14-22): Winery events and agritourism activities must comply with county noise regulations, restricting loud operations during night hours to minimize disturbance to surrounding communities

rules.title: OSHA Hazard Communication Standard
rules.shortDescription: Employers must have a written hazard communication program and provide information and training to employees regarding hazardous chemicals in the workplace
rules.fullText: OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (29 CFR §1910.1200): Employers must have a written hazard communication program and provide information and training to employees regarding hazardous chemicals in the workplace

rules.title: California Occupational Safety and Health Act
rules.shortDescription: Employers must develop an Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP), which includes identifying workplace hazards, and ensuring health and safety training for employees
rules.fullText: California Occupational Safety and Health Act (Cal/OSHA, Labor Code §6300 et seq.): Employers must develop an Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP), which includes identifying workplace hazards, and ensuring health and safety training for employees

rules.title: Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)
rules.shortDescription: Employers with 50 or more employees must provide eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per year for specified family and medical reasons
rules.fullText: Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) (29 CFR Part 825): Employers with 50 or more employees must provide eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per year for specified family and medical reasons

rules.title: California Family Rights Act (CFRA)
rules.shortDescription: Employers with 5 or more employees must provide eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid protected leave for family-care and medical reasons, including leave to care for a domestic partner or child
rules.fullText: California Family Rights Act (CFRA) (Gov. Code §12945.2): Employers with 5 or more employees must provide eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid protected leave for family-care and medical reasons, including leave to care for a domestic partner or child

rules.title: California Paid Family Leave (PFL)
rules.shortDescription: Provides up to 8 weeks of partial pay to employees who take time off to care for a seriously ill family member or bond with a new child
rules.fullText: California Paid Family Leave (PFL) (Unemp. Ins. Code §3300-3306): Provides up to 8 weeks of partial pay to employees who take time off to care for a seriously ill family member or bond with a new child

rules.title: California Wage and Hour Laws
rules.shortDescription: Non-exempt employees are entitled to overtime pay at the rate of one and a half times the regular rate for hours worked beyond 8 hours per day or 40 hours per week
rules.fullText: California Wage and Hour Laws (IWC Wage Orders): Non-exempt employees are entitled to overtime pay at the rate of one and a half times the regular rate for hours worked beyond 8 hours per day or 40 hours per week

rules.title: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
rules.shortDescription: Businesses must make reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities unless doing so would cause undue hardship
rules.fullText: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. §12101 et seq.): Businesses must make reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities unless doing so would cause undue hardship

rules.title: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA)
rules.shortDescription: Businesses that collect personal information from California residents and meet criteria such as having annual gross revenues of $25 million or more must comply with consumer privacy rights
rules.fullText: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) (Cal. Civ. Code §1798.100 et seq.): Businesses that collect personal information from California residents and meet criteria such as having annual gross revenues of $25 million or more must comply with consumer privacy rights
